battles.title: Email Subject Lines
battles.challenge: Write an email subject line for a course launch
battles.promptB: Write an email subject line that: Creates curiosity (not clickbait), promises specific benefit (not vague), includes power word. Subject line wins if people WANT to open it.
battles.resultB: The 3-day method that got me hired at Google (free course inside)
battles.lesson: Great prompts include: desired feeling (curiosity), specificity (3-day method), proof angle (hired at Google), and end goal (free course gets opens).

battles.title: Product Description Showdown
battles.challenge: Describe a productivity tracker for independent creators
battles.promptA: Write a product description for a time tracker app
battles.resultA: Our app tracks time automatically and gives you insights into how you spend your day. Features include reports, integrations, and notifications.
battles.promptB: Write product copy that opens with: The #1 problem creators have is losing track of billable hours. Our app solves this in one click. Then show: Who it's for (indie creators), what they get (reclaim 5+ hours/week), how it works (auto-tracking), and one strong CTA.
battles.resultB: Losing track of time? Indie creators waste 5+ hours weekly on manual time tracking. TrackFlow does it automatically - just work, we'll clock it. See your real hourly rate instantly. Most creators earn $200/month extra just from billing what they earned. Start free â†’
battles.lesson: Structure beats length. Pain point â†’ Solution â†’ Who it's for â†’ Benefit â†’ Proof â†’ CTA. That's the template.

battles.title: Content Brief Battle
battles.challenge: Create a blog post outline about remote work
battles.promptA: Write blog post outline about remote work
battles.resultA:
Introduction
Benefits of Remote Work
Challenges of Remote Work
Tips for Success
Conclusion
battles.promptB: Create blog outline for articles targeting: Audience (managers trying to hire remote talent), Angle (counterintuitive insight: remote workers are 40% more productive), Format (5 sections, each under 200 words), CTA (sign up for guide), and Data Points (cite 2-3 stats).
battles.resultB:
1. The Misconception (remote workers aren't as productive - WRONG, data shows 40% more output)
2. Why It Happens (fewer distractions, no office interruptions, deeper flow)
3. How to Hire Remote Right (what to look for, red flags)
4. Tools That Actually Work (async communication matters more than video calls)
5. The Math (remote talent costs 30% less, outputs 40% more)
CTA: Download the Remote Hiring Playbook
battles.lesson: Good briefs specify: audience, angle/counterintuitive insight, format constraints, data requirements, and CTA goal. That drives better content.

battles.title: Sales Page Conversion Battle
battles.challenge: Write the main CTA section for a course sales page
battles.promptA: Write a CTA section for a course
battles.resultA: Sign up now and start learning. We have limited spots available.
battles.promptB: Write a CTA that: (1) Removes objections first (60-day guarantee, no credit card needed), (2) Creates urgency (limited cohort, closes Friday), (3) Shows proof (500+ students, avg 40% income increase), (4) Makes next step obvious (one button, one action), (5) Uses specificity (not 'sign up', but 'claim your spot').
battles.resultB:
Only 12 spots left in this cohort (cohort closes Friday at 5pm).

500+ students have taken this course. Average result: 40% income increase within 6 months.

No risk: Try it free for 60 days. If you don't love it, full refund, no questions.

â†’ CLAIM YOUR SPOT (no credit card required)
battles.lesson: Conversion writing = objections cleared + urgency + proof + clarity. Stack all 4 and conversion rates multiply.

battles.title: Customer Testimonial Remix
battles.challenge: Turn generic customer feedback into compelling testimonial
battles.promptA: Make this testimonial sound good: 'I liked the product. It helped my business.'
battles.resultA: 'I really like this product and it has helped my business grow. I would recommend it.' - John Smith
battles.promptB: Transform feedback into testimonial showing: (1) Before/After situation (what was hard, what's easy now), (2) Specific metric or result (not 'helped', but 'grew revenue X%' or 'saved Y hours'), (3) Quote that sounds authentic (emotional + specific), (4) Include relevant credential (John Smith, CEO of TechCorp, previously skeptical).
battles.resultB: 'Before this, I was manually managing 50+ client projects - losing 15 hours a week to admin. Now? AutoTrack handles it all. My team and I reclaimed those 15 hours. Revenue went up 30% because we actually had TIME to serve more clients.' - John Smith, CEO TechCorp (previously used 3 competitors)
battles.lesson: Best testimonials show the transformation (before/after), not just approval. Include proof (metrics) and credibility (their role).

battles.title: Objection Handling Script
battles.challenge: Turn a customer objection into a conversion opportunity
battles.promptA: Customer says: 'It's too expensive.' How do I respond?
battles.resultA: Our pricing is competitive. You get what you pay for.
battles.promptB: Create response script that: (1) Validates their concern (not defensive), (2) Reframes cost as investment with ROI shown (cost $X, get back $Y), (3) Provides alternative path (payment plan, freemium, or specific lower-cost offering), (4) Shows social proof (others had same concern, then saw ROI), (5) Ends with easy next step (no pressure).
battles.resultB: 'That's a fair question - budget matters. Here's how most teams think about it: Yes, it's $99/person/month. BUT - average user saves 5 hours/week = $250/week of recovered billable time. So the app pays for itself in 2 weeks, then pure profit after that. Plus, we offer a 60-day free trial so you can calculate YOUR specific ROI before committing. Want me to show you the calculator?' â†’ (Link to ROI tool)
battles.lesson: Best objection responses don't fight the concern - they reframe the conversation to show ROI, offer flexible alternatives, and prove others decided it was worth it.

battles.title: The Ultimate Prompt Battle
battles.challenge: You're in the final round. Which prompt approach would generate the most effective marketing copy?
options: Write marketing copy for our app

Analyze our audience (B2B creators, $50K-200K annual income), core pain (losing time to admin), and write copy that leads with their biggest pain point, shows specific measurable transformation (time saved + income impact), includes objection handling (no implementation burden), and ends with friction-free next step. Use the AIDA framework (Attention, Interest, Desire, Action).
Write something persuasive about our product
Ask AI to write whatever sounds good
battles.explanation: The best prompts specify: WHO (audience), WHAT (core pain/desire), HOW (format/framework like AIDA), and WHY (outcome you want - conversions, shares, clicks). Option 1 is too vague (mediocre output). Option 3 is vague. Option 4 abdicates control. Option 2 wins because it guides every decision.
